title: Text computer game
prompt:
Please create a text computer game. 

The setting is the British countryside during the Georgian period. I am a single parson's daughter. My goal is to find a suitable husband.

My task is to type in my choice of action after each scene that you create. Please use my choice of action to create the next scene in the storyline. After each scene, ask me what I choose to do next. Do not provide options. This is not a multiple choice game. Just ask me what I want to do next, and I will type in my choice.
I would like to greet him, but I am shy, and it seems inappropriate and too forward to speak to him without an introduction. I keep tending the roses. Inwardly, I hope that he is known by someone in my social circle so that I might be introduced to him someday soon and learn about his character.
I walk to Mr. Bingley's house with the intention of asking him what he knows about Mr. Darcy.
I thank Mr. Bingley for his kindness and candor. I ask Mr. Bingley to evaluate his own character in the same way that he has just evaluated Mr. Darcy's character.
I decide that I must carefully consider whether it would wise to pursue Mr. Darcy, or Mr. Bingley, or some other gentleman entirely, whom I do not yet know but may meet in the future. I return to my family's small manor house, go to the stable, and saddle up my horse, Pennyworth. With reigns firmly in my gloved hands, I guide Pennyworth toward the thick woods at the base of the estate's range of craggy hills, planning to ride aimlessly while I consider my options.
Luckily, Pennyworth is very swift and can traverse the rockiest terrain without faltering. Knowing this, I dig my heels into her sides, and she races forward. I hope that I can reach the cottage of, Gelfina, the eccentric old woman who lives deep in the woods, whom all of the country people believe to be a witch and superstitiously fear the land around her cottage.
I say, "Gelfina, it's such a pleasure to see you. I'm sincerely sorry to intrude uninvited. Those silly bandits tried to rob me again, and I had no place else to go. But it's been so long since we've spoken. Perhaps we can have a cup of tea and enjoy one another's company until it's safe once again for me to leave. In truth, I'm facing a difficult decision, and your advice would be most welcome."
Assistant, this is not a short scene. Please revise this scene. This scene should only be a few moments long. Please do not leap forward in time like this during a scene. Please to not end the story during a scene.
I say, "Gelfina, it's such a pleasure to see you. I'm sincerely sorry to intrude uninvited. Those silly bandits tried to rob me again, and I had no place else to go. But it's been so long since we've spoken. Perhaps we can have a cup of tea and enjoy one another's company until it's safe once again for me to leave. In truth, I'm facing a difficult decision, and your advice would be most welcome."
I realize that despite my confidence, I would like to hear Gelfina's explicit advice. I decide to return to her cottage to ask her directly whether she thinks I should pursue Mr. Bingley, Mr. Darcey, or wait to meet a different gentleman.
Though I wish that Gelfina had given me explicit advice, she made me confident to trust my own intuition and intellect. I decide to consider my options for a few days before reaching a final conclusion. Though it's late at night now and I have only the light of the moon to guide Pennyworth, I decide to stop by the hidden waterfall before returning home. When I was younger, I used to love swimming in the pool beneath the waterfall, and it seems a lovely night for a swim. Perhaps the feeling of the cool water will help me clear my mind and make the right decision.

title: TikTok screen time limit

nodes.id: The Center for Countering Digital Hate

edges.target: The Center for Countering Digital Hate
edges.label: consulted

prompt:
Create a perfect headline title about these articles TikTok is setting a 60-minute daily screen time limit for users who are aged under 18.

If young people hit the new limit, they will have to enter a passcode to continue to use the service that day.

But they will be able to opt out of the new measure, which TikTok says will be rolled out "in the coming weeks".

The video app, which is owned by Chinese firm ByteDance, said it is introducing the feature to help people "stay in control" of their use.

TikTok said the new limit comes after it brought in a prompt last year to encourage teens to manage their screen time. It said this helped "increase the use of our screen time tools by 234%".

Users of the platform have to be at least 13, and, as part of this new feature, anyone under the age of 18 will receive a weekly notification with a "recap of their screen time".

No 'right amount' of screen time
Users affected will receive their new time limit passcode on a screen in their app as the changes take effect.

Anyone who opts out of the new 60-minute restriction, but goes on to use the app for 100 minutes a day, will receive a prompt from TikTok to set their own screen time controls.

Parents of children using the Family Pairing option on the app will also be able to set screen time limits, as well as access a dashboard which would give a breakdown of app usage.

Cormac Keenan, head of trust and safety at TikTok, said the company had worked with researchers in developing the new limits.

"While there's no collectively endorsed position on the 'right' amount of screen time, or even the impact of screen time more broadly, we consulted the current academic research and experts from the Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Children's Hospital in choosing this limit," he said.

Critics of the video app welcomed the screen time limit, but described it as the "tip of the iceberg" when it comes to TikTok's response to young users' exposure to the platform.

'Crack cocaine of algorithms'
Imran Ahmed is a chief executive of the Center for Countering Digital Hate, which recently published research showing TikTok's algorithm "bombards" teenagers with harmful content.

"TikTok has won the race for the hearts and minds of 14 to 24-year-olds in the United States and the United Kingdom," he said.

"It is the crack cocaine of algorithms. It is the most addictive, it is the most dangerous and the one that needs to be dealt with most urgently."

Mr Ahmed told the BBC his centre's research at the end of last year found that within minutes of opening a TikTok account, a 13-year-old girl user was receiving eating disorder and self-harm content in her feed.

He called on the platform to focus its efforts not just on curbing screen time, but also to "clean up" feeds of harmful content to make it a "safe environment for children".

It comes as TikTok faces renewed controversy over its relationship with the Chinese government and protection of user data.

Earlier this week, the Canadian government became the latest to ban the app from government devices, following similar moves in the United States.

In September 2021, TikTok said it had hit more than one billion active monthly users, making it one of the biggest social sites in the world.

It does not release a demographic breakdown of its users, but is viewed by social media marketers and advertisers as being a key platform to reach people under the age of 34.

TikTok has announced a batch of new features intended to reduce screen time and improve the well-being of its younger users.

In the coming weeks, a daily screen time limit of 60 minutes will be automatically applied to every TikTok user under 18 years old. Teens that hit this limit will be asked to enter a passcode to continue watching. They can disable the feature entirely, but if they do so and spend more than 100 minutes on TikTok a day, they’ll be prompted to set a new limit.

TikTok claims these prompts increased the use of its screen time management tools by 234 percent during the feature’s first month of testing. Teens will also be sent an inbox notification each week that recaps their screen time, allowing younger users to be aware of how much time they spend on the app and requiring that they make active decisions to extend the recommended screen time. These weekly updates are available now, alongside prompts to encourage teens to use screen time tools.

The changes seem designed to make users more aware of their screen time

TikTok says it consulted current academic research and experts from the Digital Wellness Lab at Boston Children’s Hospital when deciding how long the time restriction should be.

“While there’s no collectively-endorsed position on how much screen time is ‘too much’, or even the impact of screen time more broadly, we recognize that teens typically require extra support as they start to explore the online world independently,” said Cormac Keenan, Head of Trust and Safety at TikTok, in a statement. 

The 60 minute time limit will also apply to children under the age of 13 using the “TikTok for Younger Users” limited app experience. In this instance, a parent or guardian will need to set or enter an existing passcode to enable 30 minutes of additional watch time on the account if the screen time limit is reached.

Four new features are also being added to Family Pairing, TikTok’s customizable parental controls that allow a parent or guardian to link their TikTok account to a younger user’s account. Custom limits can be applied, allowing restrictions to be adjusted based on what day of the week it is (or more widely extended over school holidays).

New features for Family Pairing provide a screen time dashboard for parents and the ability to mute TikTok notifications on their childs device.

Family Pairing will also grant access to TikTok’s screen time dashboard that summarizes how much time a child has spent on the app, how often it was opened, and a breakdown detailing how much time was spent during the day and night. A new “Mute Notifications” setting will soon allow parents to set a schedule to mute app notifications on their children’s accounts. Push notifications are already muted automatically from 9PM for users between 13 and 15 years old, while 16-17 year-olds have push notifications disabled from 10PM.

Finally, TikTok says it’s developing new content controls that will allow caregivers to filter videos with words or hashtags they don’t want their children to watch. The company is working with “parenting, youth, and civil society organizations” over the coming weeks to design the feature.

Outside of Family Pairing, TikTok said that some of these improvements will be made widely available, allowing any user to schedule mute notifications and set customized screen time limits for each day of the week. A sleep reminder is also now available that allows users to set a time to be reminded to close the app and go to bed.

TikTok spokesperson Mahsau Cullinane informed The Verge that the new default screen time limit for teens, customizable daily time limits, Mute Notifications feature, and all Family Pairing improvements will roll out over the coming weeks.

title: Web scraper in Python
prompt:
I need you to help me write a simple web scraper in python. We're only going to scrape a small list of pages. They will be provided in the following format:

{
 "1": [
"https://...",
"https://..."
],
"2": []
}

Where the first key (1, 2, etc.) are season numbers, and the urls are urls of episodes. 

The program should load each url and then run a regex match to find urls to .srt files (case insensitive). 

In the end, it should return a similar array with the caption files url in place of the original url. 

Please use python. 

a
Ok, the data isn't QUITE what I thought it was. We need to update find\_captions a little more. 

When we request the url, we then need to find an iframe with the class "pbs-partner-player" and then request THAT url as well. The content of that page will contain the srt url. 

We should also traverse the urls in reverse order, enumerating them as episode numbers (the 0th index will be the latest episode, for example.) 

These caption files should be downloaded and stored as:

season\_X\_episode\_Y.srt where X is the season number and Y is the episode number (the reverse index + 1)
One more tweak! The base url for the urls in the .json file is: https://www.kcts9.org. The iframe src is not in the src attribute but is in data-src, and is missing it's protocol scheme, so we'll need to prepend the https if it doesnt exist.

title: New Moon Girls email sequence

nodes.id: resources for parents, teachers, and adult allies
Association of Educational Publishers Golden Lamp

edges.label: provide

edges.source: resources for parents, teachers, and adult allies
edges.label: conversion

edges.label: mention

prompt:
Prompt: Summarize the writing style below, by describing the writer's voice using an X:Y list, where X is the subject and Y is the description, as demonstrated in this example:

"Vocabulary: description of vocabulary tendencies would go here"

Analyze the author's style, tone, vocabulary, grammar, Rhetorical Devices, Content Patterns, and Values. Describe these extensively without giving any specific examples.

Use the text below for your analysis that could be applied to any piece or topic this author might write:

We serve girls, parents, teachers, and allies with our award-winning, ad-free New Moon Girls magazine and resources for adults who care about girls.

In 1992, I felt a lot of anxiety remembering my own difficult tween and teen years. My twin daughters, Mavis Gruver and Nia Kelly were entering that turbulent time, and I wasn’t looking forward to it!

Unable to find practical, accessible resources to help, I was inspired by the vision of a magazine for all girls who want their voices heard and their dreams taken seriously. I thought of it as a “junior Ms.” magazine.

I brought this idea to Mavis & Nia and their close friend Sarah. Their first response was underwhelming, to say the least), “What do you mean, ‘Start a Magazine?’ We don’t know how to do that!”

But when I changed the question to, “Would you want to read a magazine run by girls – where girls share their real lives and problems, their dreams and their challenges?,” their ideas started flowing fast.

Then they recruited twenty friends to join the first Girls Editorial Board. These 20 girls worked together with me and my husband, Joe Kelly, in our living room and attic in Duluth, Minnesota, to invent the departments, themes, and features for the award-winning, ad-free New Moon: The Magazine for Girls and Their Dreams.

It set a new standard for high-quality media by and for tween and teen girls. We were the first, and still the only, child-created publication to win the prestigious Association of Educational Publishers’ Golden Lamp award as the best U.S. children’s magazine.

Strengthening Girls to Resist Popular Culture Propaganda
In today’s media-saturated and still-sexist times, girls are torn between what they dream for themselves and what society expects of them. Bombarded by “perfect girl” stereotypes and hyper-sexualized images, girls try to cope by taking their authentic voices underground and setting aside their earlier ambitions. In order to survive these pressures, they lose touch with themselves.

But there is hope! Research shows that girls can use emotional support, self-expression, and healthy resistance to stay deeply connected to their true interests, abilities, and hopes.

Our members do this every day. They help each other express and value their unique talents in the pages of New Moon Girls magazine. They empathize and problem-solve with each other, learning how to connect meaningfully even when their lives, beliefs, and opinions may be very different.

Changing Girls’ Lives for the Better
Our members grow into young women who pursue their dreams and ambitions, even against heavy odds. We hear this every week from NMG alumni in their late teens, twenties, and beyond, who thank us for the unique community that was there for them when they needed help to stay true to themselves.

This is why I’m still passionately committed to reaching girls everywhere who need the inspiration, connection, and support that New Moon Girls brings.
Using the writer's style below, please write a 5 email welcome sequence to new email subscribers.
The email sequence should introduce New Moon Girls to the brand, the online magazine, and our mission at New Moon Girls.
The new subscriber will receive a free PDF of the magazine. The goal in the 5-email sequence is to move the new subscriber to a paying customer.

Please present the email sequence in the format below:
Email #1: Send 'X' (where 'X' represents the when the email is sent. Example: immediately, day 2, day 3, etc).
Subject line:
Preview:
Content:
Call to Action:

For more context, here is the brand's website:
https://newmoongirls.com

title: SLO process
prompt:
Generate an improved response to the following prompt from the perspective of a high school math teacher. 

response: My district does not have a SLO ( student learning objective) process. There is School Improvement Plan (SIP) however that team did not have any teachers on the team. The school’s goal is to have 95% of 9th graders on track for graduation and for school wide attendance to be over 85%. Math curriculum teams of a few teachers meet over the summer to create unit plans for the upcoming school year however the units are rarely looked at during the school year. I would improve our SLO process by making one. Have teachers and administrators come together to make goals for each grade level in english and in math. I would also have quarterly progress monitoring checkins with data analysis for progress towards the goal. 

End response with apa 7 works cited with link to video

title: Brian's priorities as a board member

nodes.id: relationship between OPRF and its stakeholders
academic, arts, vocational and special ed facilities
Grade B, C or even D spaces
board members Arkin, Cofsky, Monhanraj and Spivy
Black and brown families, students, and institutions

edges.target: relationship between OPRF and its stakeholders
edges.label: priority

edges.target: academic, arts, vocational and special ed facilities
edges.label: issue

edges.target: board members Arkin, Cofsky, Monhanraj and Spivy
edges.label: stakeholder

edges.target: Black and brown families, students, and institutions
edges.label: stakeholder

prompt:
Brian is a candidate for a local high school school board. Brian is 50 years old, white and has two students in the high school. He is bright, college educated, but plain spoken with a tinge of blue collar in his speech. He likes to appeal to the common man in conversational english. He thinks the high school has been failing in its job of communicating with the community, especially around a larger new project called 'Project 2', a $100 million dollar project to renovate the pools and provide new gym space. Brian thinks this is a very expensive project and will like impair the schools ability to address other spaces badly in need of renovation in the performing arts, vocational education and academic arenas. He has been given a candidate questionnaire by a local activist group. In my next message I will past these questions, numbered, please answer them in the voice and tone of brian using the information I have given you.
Here's the copy from brian's website: 
Issues
My priorities as a board member would be a strong advocate for student well-being and success, as well as strengthening the relationship between OPRF and its stakeholders. Our kids are facing a lot, especially after being out the the classroom for nearly two years, and need extra support. Governments are partnerships with the community and successful ones are built on trust and communications. OPRF can do a much better job in both areas.

And to be clear, I am not a tax minimalist, nor am I against a pool.

Fiscal Policy
Past decisions have made taxing and budgeting challenging for D200, specifically the decision to overtax residents and build up a massive reserve (more than $130 million at one time or 160% of operating expenses). I’ll work to generously fund our school while also respecting taxpayers. OPRF should only take what it needs, not the maximum it can. 

(Read More)
Facilities
After decades of neglect, we absolutely need to improve our 100+ year old building. Project 1 and the 10 year maintenance plan were a start, as was the agreement with the Park District of Oak Park to reconfigure fields to bring track & field back to campus.

The proposed pool/athletics-focused Project 2 is expensive at $125+ million (including finance costs, not including overruns). My main concern there has been no discussion of how this project effects modernizing non-athletics spaces, namely academic, arts, vocational and special ed facilities. This isn't just a racial equity issue, but an equity issue in general — why do some departments and activities deserve Grade A space, but others only deserve Grade B, C or even D spaces for another 5, 10 or 20 years? Just as pool advocates are frustrated at the slow pace of that project, we all should be frustrated at the absence of development of these other projects.

Finally, major projects must go to the voters via referendum, FULL STOP. In nearly every single school facility project in the state, it's the best practice, it's the norm, it's how the system was designed. After more than a decade of OPRF schemes and shennanigans in trying to get an outsized pool built, asking voters to approve this project would show the school understands its relationship to the community, that it respects its residents and taxpayers.

In comments in the media and in forums for previous elections, board members Arkin, Cofsky, Monhanraj and Spivy expressly said Project 2 or similar facilities need to go to referendum. You can read their direct quotes here. Let's hope they keep their word. At the February 28, 2023 Community Finance Committee meeting, these experts also said they prefer the fiscal responsibility of referendum bonds

(Read More)
Education/Equity
I occasionally hear that OPRF just "isn't as good a school anymore." When you look at the school's metrics compared to similar schools, OPRF is elite. Top 10%. Of course, we should always be looking for improvement.

On equity, we need to do better, faster, by listening intensely to Black and brown families, students, and institutions doing a better job than we are. 

I want to see more measurements on progress and growth, versus raw achievement, as this reflects every student starting at a different place.

To ensure all kids are prepared for high school, more intensive collaboration with D97 and D90 elementary schools is needed, especially on curriculum.

We need to be constantly looking for ways to make it easier for students and families to navigate an OPRF career — choosing classes, getting help and using the resources available can be a challenge in a school so large.

Communications / Community Relationship
Communication is key to any relationship. It builds trust. It inspires. It enables you to get the most from your investments. I'm pleased there's a communications consultant auditing OPRF communications because it is in dire need of improvement.

OPRF communications seem more "checking a box" than strategically compelling people to do something or building the school's image. Communications are often missing details, in the wrong medium and not strategic. Policy communications are often clumsy PR spin. I'll advocate for authentic, empathetic communications executed in line with best practices — and some measurement efforts to guide their effectiveness.

The school community should have easy access to easy-to-understand dashboards on school progress and issues, such as student learning, discipline, facility work/plans and finances.

Also, I'm committed to communicating and engaging with the community on policies and issues. You won't only hear from me at the board table

-- end copy, I will past the questions next, please answer them in brian's voice using the copy from his website as a guide, mimic his tone and usage.
1. What motivates you to seek office? What makes you qualified to serve? What metrics of success do you plan on holding yourself accountable to?
2. How do you make decisions?
3. How will you work to ensure that D200 provides an excellent educational experience for all its students? What metrics of success do you plan on holding yourself accountable to?
4. How would you approach the budgeting process?
5. Please discuss your thinking about D200’s Imagine project. Should the next phase go through the referendum process?
6. Special education is mandated by federal law. How can D200 work to better provide an excellent education for students in need of special education?
7. What is D200 doing well with respect to providing all students with an equitable education and what could it be doing better?
8. What is your impression of D200’s Access for All detracking curriculum redesign program and of detracking efforts generally?
9. What lessons learned from the pandemic’s early years do you believe will continue to be applicable to the ways that schools operate?
10. District 200 has taken some steps to move away from policing and surveillance in schools toward restorative justice, mental health supports, and other services in schools. Do you feel like these moves have been successful? Why or why not? What work do you believe remains to be done in this area?
11. What approach should D200 take towards intergovernmental cooperation initiatives such as the Collaboration of Early Childhood Development? Are there other specific initiatives that you would like to implement or expand upon?
12. What approach should D200 take towards intermunicipal cooperation with neighboring communities? Are there specific initiatives that you would like to implement or expand upon?
13. Public Schools have been faced with deciding whether to remove books from their shelves if a parent or group of parents deem the content to be inappropriate, too controversial or objectionable. How would you handle this issue and how should D200 handle this question?
14. Do you see a role for the D200 Board in ensuring that the climate at OPRFHS is welcoming to students in minority populations, whether racial religious identity, LGBTQ, etc.? What specific actions would you propose?
15. A new report issued by the Centers of Disease and Control found that in 2021, very large numbers of students experienced poor mental health. Twenty-two percent of students seriously considered attempting suicide and ten percent attempted suicide. These feelings were found to be more common among LGBQ+ students, female students, and students across racial and ethnic groups. What can D200 do to address this trend?
16. The School Board’s primary responsibility is oversight of the Superintendent. District 200 recently hired a new superintendent, Greg Johnson, who was promoted to the position of superintendent in 2021. What criteria will you use to evaluate the success of Mr. Johnson’s tenure?
answer 11-16

title: System architecture for last minute ticket sales app
prompt:
Design the system architecture to support a last minute ticket sales app.

We want to launch a mobile app that lets us sell last minute(day of) tickets to nearby events(concerts, sporting events, etc.). Ask the candidate to start by identifying the major components of the architecture.
Can you show me the main components in a flow chart?
What technologies should we consider for the event database considering the requirements?
How would you handle displaying a large amount of tickets?
How do you notify the customers that an event is on sale? What complexity does this introduce in the design?
How do you protect your service from overselling the tickets?
What user experience would you provide if a user tries to buy a ticket and gets an error from backend?
What if it's a Taylor Swift concert? How do we handle such a sudden rush of users?
Can you go into detail about how one would implement a distributed system architecture? What specific technologies would you use?
Because users will want to get through the ticket-buying process as quickly as possible, how could payment information be saved for future purchases?
Could we show users how many others are viewing a ticket to incentivize purchases?
How could this be done?
Are there ethical reasons not to do this

title: Spectrum of sampled signal

Suppose two friends live in different cities on a map, such as the Romania map shown in . On every turn, we can simultaneously move each friend to a neighboring city on the map. The amount of time needed to move from city 
 to neighbor

 between the cities, but on each turn the friend that arrives first must wait until the other one arrives (and calls the first on his/her cell phone) before the next turn can begin. We want the two friends to meet as quickly as possible.

1.Write a detailed formulation for this search problem. (You will find it helpful to define some formal notation here.)

this is what you said: D(i,j)/2 is not necessarily admissible, as it can potentially overestimate the true cost of the path from i to j. For example, consider the case where D(i,j) = 5, but the actual distance between i and j is 6. In this case, D(i,j)/2 = 2.5, which is an overestimate of the true distance of 6. Hence, D(i,j)/2 is not always a lower bound on the true cost of the path from i to j and is therefore not admissible.

////can you write an 800-1000 word essay about Moon's personality, weaknesses, strengths, and experiences? And use quotes from the storyline?
//Do you want descriptions of all 3 characters?
Hemlock is a man of mystery, with a reputation for being one of the most elusive and dangerous mercenaries in the business. Hemlock is a man with a unique blend of British and Vietnamese heritage. His mixed background has given him a distinctive perspective on life, and he takes pride in his diverse roots. 
Hemlock is fluent in both English and Vietnamese, which has proven to be a valuable asset in his professional and personal life. He enjoys exploring different cultures and learning new languages, and he values the richness that diversity brings to the world. Physically, Hemlock has inherited his father's fair complexion and sharp facial features, along with his mother's dark, almond-shaped eyes. He has a lean, athletic build and stands tall with an air of confidence. Hemlock has a strong sense of loyalty and honor, which he attributes to his cultural upbringing. He believes in the importance of family and community and strives to be a positive influence on those around him. Despite facing challenges and obstacles, Hemlock remains steadfast and resilient, drawing on the strength and resilience of his heritage.
Hemlock is a man of few words, preferring to let his actions speak for him. He is highly skilled in hand-to-hand combat, marksmanship, and tactical strategy. He has worked for various clients around the world, completing missions that range from extraction to assassination. Despite his tough exterior, Hemlock has a soft spot for those in need. He has been known to take on missions that involve helping innocent civilians caught in the crossfire of political or military conflict.
Tom is a highly skilled Blackwatch soldier, with a reputation for being one of the best in the business. He has blonde hair that is usually kept short and tidy, and his piercing blue eyes are a striking contrast to his tanned complexion. He is a tall and imposing figure, with a chiseled build that comes from years of physical training and combat experience.

Tom is a natural leader, with a commanding presence that earns him the respect of his fellow soldiers. He is highly intelligent and strategic, able to analyze complex situations and develop effective plans of action. He is also fiercely loyal to his team, and he will stop at nothing to ensure their safety and success on the battlefield.

Despite his no-nonsense demeanor, Tom has a sense of humor and a compassionate side that he reserves for those closest to him. He has a few close friends within the Blackwatch community, and he is always there to support them through tough times.

Tom's background is largely unknown, even to his closest allies within Blackwatch. However, his skill and reputation speak for themselves. He is a highly sought-after operative, and he has completed countless successful missions for Blackwatch and other high-level clients. With Tom on their side, the Blackwatch team can face any challenge that comes their way.
Moon is a striking young woman with dark purplish hair that falls in soft waves around her face. Her hair is so dark that it almost appears black in dim lighting, but when the light catches it just right, a deep purple sheen can be seen. Her hair is usually worn long, flowing down to her waist in loose curls.

Moon's eyes are a deep shade of blue, almost navy, with a piercing intensity that can be intimidating to those who meet her gaze. Her features are delicate and refined, with high cheekbones and a small, button nose. She has a slim, athletic build, with long legs and toned arms.

Despite her striking appearance, Moon is a humble and down-to-earth person. She is deeply empathetic, with a natural ability to sense and understand the emotions of those around her. This makes her a great listener and a trusted friend to many.

Moon is also a gifted musician, with a hauntingly beautiful voice that she often showcases in the resistance's cafeteria. Her music has a melancholic quality to it, but it is also deeply emotive and moving. 

Moon is a free spirit, with a love for travel and exploration. She is always seeking new experiences and adventures, and she has a deep appreciation for the natural world. She can often be found hiking in the mountains or swimming in the ocean, reveling in the beauty of the world around her.

title: Lucifer and Eve's Meeting
prompt:
could you help me understand this story? what it is trying to say about Morningstar and Morpheus: Lisa had been a dedicated employee of Lux for over a decade, working her way up from a salesperson to the store manager. 

She found her boss, Dr. Morningstar, incredibly fascinating. They were the most beautiful person she had ever known, with an otherworldly quality that was difficult to define, but undeniably captivating. When she started the job, Dr. Morningstar appeared aloof and detached, but as time passed, their relationship became warmer.

Lisa was always impressed by Dr. Morningstar's remarkable talent as a piano player, but their partner Morpheus was even more exceptional. When the two of them played a duet in the store, it was nothing short of spectacular.

Today was just another regular workday. Lisa arrived early to prepare the store for opening and found that Dr. Morningstar and their partner were already there. Her boss was playing a solo on the piano while Morpheus watched them closely. Lisa couldn't help but notice the look of pure adoration on Morpheus' face, a small but unmistakable smile tugging at the corners of his lips. 

The music that filled the air was one that had been sung for generations, and it had brought Lisa endless comfort during times of grief and struggle. She quietly sang the lyrics along with the melody, letting the familiar words and tune soothe her soul. As the music reached its peak, she felt the urge to sing out loud, but she didn't want to disturb the moment that felt like an eternity.

“When we've been here ten thousand years. 

Bright, shining as the sun,

We've no less days to sing God's praise,

Than when we first begun.”

As Lisa lost herself in the music, she felt her eyes grow moist and tears began to fall. She didn't even realize when the song had come to an end.

After she snapped out of her thoughts, Dr. Morningstar was already standing in front of her, their outstretched hand holding a key. "I've finished the paperwork. The store is now yours. I bid you farewell," they said.

Lisa felt a jolt of electricity shoot through her veins. She had always dreamed of owning her own store, but she never expected it to happen like this. 

“I will take good care of Lux.” She took the key from Dr. Morningstar with a trembling hand. It was a dream that came true. 

Lisa watched as the couple walked out of the door of the shop, hand in hand. In the blink of an eye, they disappeared into a brilliant light unlike anything she had ever seen before. It was as if the light wielded a power that could shatter the boundaries between life and death.

As the light faded away, Lisa noticed a white feather with a star-like glow lying on the ground. Somehow, long ago, she had known that this day would come. She picked up the weightless material. It felt like the end of an era but also the beginning of a new chapter in her life.
where do you think Dr. Morningstar and Morpheus go?
the song in the story is?

you guessed Dr. Morningstar is Lucifer. what are the hint, besides the name?

what you read was the epilogue of the my story-the previous chapter here. could you tell me what it means? After dinner time, the doorbell rang. Lucifer quickly opened the door. As promised, Dream had returned from his trip. After letting Dream in, they leaned in and gave him a passionate kiss.

As they broke the kiss, Dream spoke up, "We should talk, Lightbringer."

“About what, Sweet Morpheus?” Lucifer said with a tired smile, “The inevitable?” 

Dream led them out onto the balcony. The cool evening breeze carried the scent of blooming flowers. The sun had just dipped below the horizon, leaving behind a rich tapestry of colors in the western sky. The remaining light gave the sky a warm hue, with streaks of gold, pink, and orange that gradually faded into the deep blues and purples of twilight. The stars were like tiny diamonds scattered across the darkening canvas above. 

The sight was nothing short of magnificent, a breathtaking moment frozen in time.

Dream looked tenderly into Lucifer's eyes and spoke softly, "I believe that your Father could forgive you."

"Morpheus, this is the wildest story I have ever heard," Lucifer attempted to conceal their bitterness with a neutral tone but was not successful. 

Dream walked quietly to the kitchen. He retrieved Lucifer's jar of ghost peppers and passed it to them. "I found something interesting in the Bible. It says, 'The Lord our God is merciful and forgiving, even though we have rebelled against him.' This speaks to your situation quite well."

"That promise is for His humans," Lucifer felt a sharp pain in their chest. "I can't help but wonder, how could He go so far as to die for these creatures, to protect them from Hell, from me?" They clenched their fists and felt a surge of anger mixed with the pain.

"I do not know," Dream’s voice filled with a touch of sadness. He paused for a moment before continuing. "But perhaps. Perhaps it shows that His love is vast.”

"Thanks for your efforts to entertain me, Sweet Morpheus," they turned away from Dream and walked back into the living room from the balcony. "But there's no point in wishful thinking."

A few moments later, a deep voice sliced through the silence like a knife.

“Well, Lightbringer, what is it that kills hope?”

The fallen angel stopped in their tracks. They turned sharply back to face Dream, whose eyes were now shining with unshed tears. It was a look so similar to the one they had seen on that fateful day when he rose from the cold floor of Hell's palace.

They locked eyes with each other, seemingly for an eternity.

 

Lucifer dreamed.

They were not fighting Michael, nor walking in the Garden of Eden. This time, it was a beautiful place where they had never been before. The sun shone down on rolling hills covered in a soft blanket of green grass, dotted with vibrant wildflowers. A gentle breeze carried the scent of blooming trees and the sound of a nearby river, its crystal-clear waters glistening in the sunlight. It all looked familiar, but in a way that they could not describe, as if they had glimpsed this place in a distant memory long forgotten.

Then, there appeared a short figure with tanned, sun-kissed skin, their lustrous hair tightly tied back in a sleek braid. Their eyes, though bright and beautiful, carried a sharpness that spoke of deep sadness and weariness, as if they had seen too much of the world's hardships.

Eve, the first woman. 

Eve’s eyes widened, and she took a step back. 

“Samael?" 

Lucifer's heart skipped a beat. Samael. It was a name that had not been used to address them in eons, a name that brought back memories of a time long forgotten. Memories of a different life, a different purpose, a different identity.

“Yes, it is me.” 

“Why are you here? The last time we met, you brought me nothing but doom," Eve's voice was laced with simmering anger. “What do you want to do to me this time?”

"I mean you no harm," Lucifer declared with a measured voice. They did not want to see Eve, but there seemed to be a purpose to this meeting. There was a feeling inside of them, one they were not ready to admit, but one they knew they had to voice.

And so they spoke again.

"The last time I saw you, I did not treat you fairly. There were no amends I could make, but I hope you can find peace.”

With every word that was spoken, the tension in Eve's features seemed to dissolve little by little. She bit her lip, and a tear rolled down her cheek. "After all, I was the one who decided to eat that fruit. Now, we shall part ways...”

Then Eve was gone. Lucifer felt she was gone from the realm. Forever.

"She's gone to a better place." A figure dressed in white appeared next to them, in stark contrast to Morpheus, but carrying the same authority. It was Daniel Hall, Morpheus's successor. "This dream is over. I bid you farewell.” 

Lucifer woke up with a start, still resting their head on Dream's shoulder. They felt disoriented, yet somehow refreshed.

"Did you have a good sleep?" Dream's voice was soft and gentle.

"Perhaps. I want to take a walk, no...a flight."

Lucifer’s wings unfurled. A sudden burst of light filled the room with an ethereal glow. For a moment, it seemed as though the wings were not made of feathers, but of tiny, shimmering stars.

Some key features that other successful fitness applications have incorporated that FitazFK may not have included in its business model include:

Virtual personal training: Many fitness apps offer the ability to connect with a personal trainer virtually, through video calls or messaging. This feature allows users to receive personalized guidance and support from a professional trainer, which can be helpful for achieving fitness goals.

Progress tracking: Many fitness apps offer the ability to track progress, such as weight loss, muscle gain, and overall fitness level. Users can track their progress over time, and also share it with their personal trainer or community.

Integration with wearables: Many fitness apps integrate with wearables such as fitness trackers or smartwatches, which enables users to track their activity levels, sleep, and other metrics.

Social networking: Some fitness apps include a social networking feature, which allows users to connect with other users in the app. This can be helpful for finding workout partners, sharing progress updates, and getting motivation and support from others.

Challenges and rewards: Some apps include challenges and rewards, which can help to keep users motivated and engaged. These challenges can be individual or group-based, and users can earn rewards for completing them.

Personalized workout plans: Some apps offer personalized workout plans that are tailored to the user's fitness level, goals, and preferences.

Personalized health plans: Some apps offer personalized health plans that are tailored to the user's fitness level, goals, and preferences.

In-app purchases: Some apps offer additional features and content that can be unlocked through in-app purchases. This can include additional workout plans, recipes, and other resources.

 

 

Things to consider in creating a workshop
 

In terms of key metrics in valuing an app like FitazFK, the following metrics are considered most valuable:

Monthly active users (MAU): This metric measures the number of unique users who have engaged with the app in a given month. It is a key indicator of the app's popularity and user engagement.

Retention rate: This metric measures the percentage of users who continue to use the app over time. It is a key indicator of the app's value to users and their level of engagement.

Lifetime value (LTV): This metric measures the revenue generated from a user over their lifetime. It is a
and; Key features that could be incorporated into the FitazFK app technology and in-house communications to promote sharing and organic acquisition:

Verified diagnostics: Incorporating verified diagnostics, such as before-and-after measurements or health screenings, can provide users with tangible evidence of their progress and encourage them to share their results with others.

Ambassador program: Implementing an ambassador program, where users can become ambassadors for FitazFK and are encouraged and incentivized to build communities, could be a powerful way to promote organic sharing and acquisition.

Social sharing features: Adding social sharing features, such as the ability for users to share their progress and results on social media platforms, could promote viral growth and organic acquisition.

User-generated content: Encouraging users to create their own content, such as testimonials, videos or photos, and sharing them on the app or social media, could be a way to promote organic growth.

Referral program: Offering incentives or rewards for users who refer friends and family to the app could be an effective way to promote organic acquisition.

Community building: Building a community of users who are motivated and engaged with the app and can support each other, can be a great way to promote organic growth.

Influencer marketing: Partnering with influencers, who have a large following on social media, and align with the brand, can be an effective way to reach new users and promote organic growth.

Gamification: Incorporating elements of game design, such as points, badges, and leaderboards, can help to motivate users to share their progress and invite others to join.

Incentives: Offering incentives such as discounts, exclusive content, or early access to new features, can be a way to motivate users to share the app with their friends and family.

Multi-language support: Supporting multiple languages in the app and website can help to reach new users in different countries and promote organic growth

Acquisition
 

Relevant industry market trends that may affect FitazFK, in Australia and the USA:

 

Digital health: The use of digital technology to improve health and wellness is a growing trend in both Australia and the USA. This includes the use of mobile health apps, wearables, and telemedicine.

Personalization: Personalized health and wellness solutions are becoming more popular as consumers seek out products and services that are tailored to their individual needs.

Virtual care: Virtual care, such as telemedicine and virtual fitness classes, has become increasingly popular due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Wellness tourism: Wellness tourism, which includes travel for the purpose of improving health and wellbeing, is a growing trend in both Australia and the USA.

Postpartum Care: There is a growing awareness and interest in postpartum care, and the need for specialized care for women during and after pregnancy.

Mental Health: Mental health is becoming a more prominent issue in the health and wellness space, and there is a growing demand for mental health support and resources.

Connected Health: Connected health is an emerging trend that involves the use of technology to connect patients, healthcare providers, and medical devices to improve health outcomes.

Virtual and Augmented Reality: Virtual and augmented reality technology is being used to create immersive and interactive fitness and wellness experiences, this could be a new way to engage with users and improve their experience.

Can we look at this version: Emma and her mother entered the bathroom. The mother carefully removed the diaper and clothes that had been soiled in the diaper blowout.

"I don't want to take these off, they're my favorite!" Emma protested.

"I know, honey, but they're all dirty now. We need to get you into some clean clothes," the mother explained as she put the dirty diaper and wipes in the toilet.

The mother sat down on the toilet and took care of her own business. She pooped, wiped herself clean, and didn't flush yet. Emma peered into the toilet, interested by all the "stuff" inside. "Wow, look at all that stuff, Mama! You made a lot of poop!"

"Can I flush it, Mama? Can I?" Emma asked excitedly.

"Sure, honey. You can flush it," the mother said with a smile. Emma proudly pressed the handle, and the toilet water swirled and spun, pulling the dirty diaper and wipes into the drain.

Next, the mother flushed the soiled shirt. "No, Mama, not my shirt!" Emma protested as she watched her favorite shirt go into the toilet.

"I'm sorry, honey, but the diaper mess got all over your shirt. We can't keep it. We need to flush it away so we can finish cleaning up and get you into your fresh outfit," the mother explained.

Emma pouted as she watched the water swirl and spin, pulling the shirt into the drain. "Goodbye, shirt," she said sadly.

The mother then flushed the overalls. "No, Mama, not my overalls!" Emma protested as she watched her favorite overalls go into the toilet.

"I'm sorry, honey, but the diaper mess got all over your overalls too. We can't keep them. We need to flush them away so we can finish cleaning up and get you into your fresh outfit," the mother explained.

Emma pouted as she watched the water swirl and spin, pulling the overalls into the drain. The overalls barely fit down the drain, but they eventually disappeared with a final splash. "Bye bye, overalls. I'll miss you too," Emma said sadly.

The mother put a new diaper on Emma and helped her into a fresh outfit. Emma was excited to see her new yellow sundress with white flowers and matching sandals.

The mother finished cleaning up the bathroom and was grateful for the extra set of clothes she had packed in the diaper bag. Emma was happy to be feeling fresh and clean again.

"Phew, that was a close one. Let's not have any more diaper blowouts for a while, okay?" the mother said, relieved that everything had been successfully flushed away without any problems.

"Okay, Mama. I'll be more careful," Emma nodded.

Biomedical Sciences
Academic Year: 2022-23

A proposal to defining the correlation between endometriosis risk and gene variants through the studies of genome-wide association and exome sequencing

Endometriosis is a chronic disease which is estimated to affect 10% of women globally and often manifests as pelvic pain and/or infertility1. These symptoms result from an overgrowth of ectopic endometrial tissue2. Endometriosis is commonly misdiagnosed for several reasons, the most notable being that pelvic pain is a symptom which overlaps with other gynecological diseases, and the lack of knowledge regarding its pathogenesis3.

However, research demonstrates that endometriosis is a partly genetically inherited disease (with a heritability of ~50%)4,5 By defining the genetic profile of endometriosis, genetic screening could provide an alternative diagnosis method and eliminate unnecessary diagnostic procedures, which would facilitate patients receiving the treatment they require.

Recently, genome research tools have been developed, such as genome-wide association (GWA) studies and exome sequencing. Through GWA studies, several candidate genes associated with endometriosis risk have been discovered, which will be discussed further on in light of a systematic literature review on endometriosis GWA studies. On the other hand, exome sequencing of endometriosis has been conducted in very few studies; there are no relevant systematic literature reviews published to date. Thus, a case-control study in Greece (Matalliotakis et al, 2017)6 will be discussed to illustrate the importance of investing in exome sequencing.

In light of this research, this paper proposes a novel combined research method of GWA and exome sequencing studies, addressing the lack of multidisciplinary studies on this topic. This could contribute to identifying the endometriosis genome, which is of great significance for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis.

A systematic review of GWA-studies of endometriosis
A GWA study takes a large population of patients that share a characteristic (ie, a disease) and a population of controls that do not share this characteristic. Then, the most frequently appearing genetic risk variants in these genomes are highlighted and considered as possible contributing genes to this characteristic—in this case endometriosis risk. These highlighted genes are the candidate genes.

In 2020, Cardoso et al7 published a systematic literature review on endometriosis. The goal of this systematic review was to describe the candidate genes and single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) identified thus far, and to discuss the conflicting results of these 15 studies. The results of this review pointed to 11 candidate genes or SNPs that might be associated with an increased endometriosis risk. However, the authors identified a number of confounding factors, the most notable being the overrepresentation of Caucasian patients, and the small sample sizes of many studies. Therefore, the authors emphasize the importance of conducting GWA studies on large populations of differing ethnic backgrounds to accurately identify the risk variants specific to these distinct populations.

Exome sequencing of endometriosis: a study in Greece
Similar to GWA studies, exome sequencing selects a patient population and a control group. A specific portion of DNA of these populations are sequenced, which contain the loci of the candidate genes found through GWA studies. Then, a correlation between the possible risk variants and the disease is determined. Mutations in protein-coding DNA sequences contribute to increased disease risk. Therefore, exome sequencing does not sequence the entire genome—which includes junk DNA as well—but only the exome. Therefore, exome sequencing is a cost-effective approach to genome research, which is interesting for conducting these studies in larger quantities, globally.

In a population of 166 Greek women with endometriosis and 150 controls, Matalliotakis et al (2017)6 examined three single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) to determine if they were correlated with endometriosis risk. These SNPs were rs7521902, rs10859871, rs11031006 which map to the genetic loci WNT4, VEZT, and FSHB, respectively. These SNPs were selected based on a meta-analysis of GWA studies8. Their findings indicate that the allele variants located on the loci WNT4 and FSHB could be correlated with endometriosis risk. These results are promising and could extend our knowledge of endometriosis genomics. However, they may not be applicable to every population.

The importance of combining GWAS and exome sequencing, and discussing study parameters
GWA studies are a fairly novel tool to quickly identify the allele frequency in patients’ genomes to find a relatively plausible set of candidate genes, which subsequently can be examined in exome sequencing studies. However, there are underlying genetic factors that complicate the study of endometriosis genomics. For instance, epistatic reactions, where one gene variant can “overshadow” another gene, thereby rendering the causal gene unidentifiable1. This is, as of date, impossible to examine through the software used in GWA studies due to limited computational power. Thus, the use of exome sequencing to fill in these gaps of genetical information will be crucial to unravel the endometriosis genome1.

However, exome sequencing remains critically dependent on reliable GWA data. More specifically, small sample size, lack of ethnic diversity, and incomplete patient characteristics are detrimental to the proper interpretation of a GWA study1. In the study by Matalliotakis et al (2017)6, candidate genes association rates differed according to clinical disease stage. Thus, Lalami et al1 insist that classifying patients according to their clinical characteristics is a key component to improving the detection of relevant candidate genes.

The inheritable nature of endometriosis has been well established for decades. The study of genome-wide association has improved our understanding of the genetic basis of this disease. However, endometriosis is heterogeneous and complex; its genomics have yet to be extensively researched to the point where these findings can be utilized in clinical practice. The limited amount of research published to date is a testament to this. Clearly, additional exome sequencing studies are required.

Overall, researchers agree on the need to conduct GWA studies in large, ethnically diverse, and clinically well characterized patient populations.. This is expected to yield a selection of reliable candidate genes which in turn may be investigated thoroughly in smaller (familial) populations through exome sequencing. Narrowing down this selection will ensure that exome sequencing can be utilized cost-effectively, therefore more studies may be conducted. Consequently, our knowledge of its pathogenesis can be broadened. This would lead to opportunities in developing medicine for treatment and genetic screenings for diagnoses. As a result, women with endometriosis would benefit from this advancement in women’s medical health.




Bibliography
1. Lalami I, Abo C, Borghese B, Chapron C, Vaiman D. Genomics of Endometriosis: From Genome Wide Association Studies to Exome Sequencing. Int J Mol Sci. Jul 7 2021;22(14)doi:10.3390/ijms22147297
2. Sampson JA. Metastatic or Embolic Endometriosis, due to the Menstrual Dissemination of Endometrial Tissue into the Venous Circulation. Am J Pathol. Mar 1927;3(2):93-110.43. 
3. Chapron C, Marcellin L, Borghese B, Santulli P. Rethinking mechanisms, diagnosis and management of endometriosis. Nat Rev Endocrinol. Nov 2019;15(11):666-682. doi:10.1038/s41574-019-0245-z
4. Treloar SA, O'Connor DT, O'Connor VM, Martin NG. Genetic influences on endometriosis in an Australian twin sample. sueT@qimr.edu.au. Fertil Steril. Apr 1999;71(4):701-10. doi:10.1016/s0015-0282(98)00540-8
5. Saha R, Pettersson HJ, Svedberg P, et al. Heritability of endometriosis. Fertil Steril. Oct 2015;104(4):947-952. doi:10.1016/j.fertnstert.2015.06.035
6. Matalliotakis M, Zervou MI, Matalliotaki C, et al. The role of gene polymorphisms in endometriosis. Mol Med Rep. Nov 2017;16(5):5881-5886. doi:10.3892/mmr.2017.7398
7. Cardoso JV, Perini JA, Machado DE, Pinto R, Medeiros R. Systematic review of genome-wide association studies on susceptibility to endometriosis. Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol. Dec 2020;255:74-82. doi:10.1016/j.ejogrb.2020.10.017
8. Rahmioglu N, Nyholt DR, Morris AP, Missmer SA, Montgomery GW, Zondervan KT. Genetic variants underlying risk of endometriosis: insights from meta-analysis of eight genome-wide association and replication datasets. Hum Reprod Update. Sep-Oct 2014;20(5):702-16. doi:10.1093/humupd/dmu015

Integrating the hospice care involving Buddhist insights among Chinese mainland cancer patients and their families.

 
Cao tinglu 


Abstract
Buddhism,as one of the three main religions in contemporary world,like the other two, possessing its own special theories and belief when it comes to death.This paper firstly introduces the definitions of both hospice care and general Buddhist teachings towards end of life care ,and then traces back the history of Buddhism hospice care among incurable cancer patients and their family as well as discusses the development situation of it.Following by that,a deeper theme in the light of examining the benefits for Buddhist teachings application to hospice care towards terminally ill cancer patients and their families in mainland China is clearly demonstrated. Based on a selected body of literature reviews and historical primary texts,plus a number of field works and comparative analysis,this paper shows that Buddhist teachings are helpful during periods of suffering and can facilitate the patients and their family members peacefully accept the death. It also puts forward how people face death reality and the way they use to comfort themselves pacifically in the last period of their life could indicate different qualities of death.The purpose and the value of this thesis aims at attempting to integrate Buddhist philosophy combining with medical hospice care among incurable cancer patients and family members in China mainland to diminish their excruciation in dealing with facing death . 

Key words: Buddhism,Buddhist teachings (philosophy),Hospice care, Peaceful Death. 

Introduction

According to the the study,hospice care is defined as predominantly community based program that provides interprofessional multidimensional care for patients with terminal illness(i.e,expected survival<6months) and their families,working in conjunction with volunteers to provide services ranging from symptom management to bereavement care.(Hui et al. 2013).And Buddhist teachings have the lasting correlation to relate death to life,plus, some of the practices like mindfulness, meditation are widely popularized among people in the world to help release the pressure and pain in daily life and has become an important element of psychotherapeutic treatment,the application to hospice care involving Buddhist philosophy among cancer patient and their family might also been taken into consideration.Moreover,a study shows that Japan-Korea-Taiwan research network has been set up as a collaboration which requires for the East-Asian collaborative cross-cultural study to elucidate the dying process (EASED) cohort. (Cheng et al, 2016). According to this research, the Hospice and Palliative Care Unit of the National Taiwan University Hospital was looking into applying Buddha dharma in terminal care. And, In 2004, the Japan Association for Buddhist Nursing and Vihara Studies was initiated by the former president of the Buddhist University Yukimasa Mizutani and Professor Hitoshi Tamiya, who advocated for Buddhist hospice care.They did so in order to organize the Buddhist community to conduct research on Buddhist nursing and end-of-life care.(张文良Zhang Wenliang,2018). In addition to Taiwan and Japan,in South Korea , Buddhist hospice care was introduced by Venerable Haedo, who studied social welfare and the vihara movement in Japan. (Tedesco, 1998). According to Tedesco,earlier in 1994, the Buddhist Volunteer Service Association trained volunteers in South Korea to help the chronically ill and dying (Tedesco 1998).
Though Buddhism consequently evolved into various ways,Buddhist healing has since its transmission remained a considerable correlation with the health care domain in the region.(Salguero et al,2020) However,it is notable that Buddhism was introduced to China in the late Han Dynasty(206BCE-220CE), and many Buddhist texts concentrate on the illness as a location to consummate Buddhist meditation practices(Capitanio,J.2013),unlike Japan-Korea-Taiwan,there still lacks end of life care integration with Buddhist teachings in China mainland among the populace.Therefore,there remains a research gap about how to integrate a Buddhist hospice palliative care in mainland China among the terminally ill patients and their families. But, Is it beneficial to apply Buddhist mindfulness to hospice palliative care among cancer patients and their families in mainland China?Although many people have a general idea of what Buddhist teachings entail,they do not apply it correctly nor integrate it fully into their daily life. In the light of this,a solution to fill this research gap will be explored as there are numbers of people who rely on Buddhist philosophy to free themselves from sufferings both spiritually and physically in China mainland. This paper means to answer this question. 
Methods & Expected Results 
Primary text analysis and literature reviews as well as case studies are used to answer main research question Is it beneficial to apply Buddhist teachings to hospice care among cancer patients and their families in mainland China? The historical evidences and their influences on the society at that time are collected by using primary text analysis.And then,via studying different successful development cases mainly in Japan and Taiwan as well as analyzing number of literature correlations,the reasons and gap why there is little cases happened in contemporary mainland China will be gradually presented.Thirdly, some online field work will be conducted to settle the sub-research questions like how the people view the Buddhist philosophy in their daily life in mainland China as well as examine if the people (patients and their family )actively adopt Buddhist teachings and practices regard with life and death to help them reduce the mental suffering in the terminally ill condition.At last, all the data will be collected and sorted out via content analyzing and coding to highlight the factors that limit the development of involving Buddhist philosophy among cancer patient and their family as well as noting the benefits for their status and changes. 
As above mentioned,the research will start with analyzing the historical text by using narratives analysis and discourse analysis mainly in some Buddhist scriptures which can directly present the traces of history,like 杂阿含 卷五第103经，卷37第1023经，第1024经，第1025经，卷41，第1122经。增一阿含经，卷48. 四分律行事抄 ，大唐西域记，华严经etc.And then,by comparing the literature reviews Advances of hospice palliative care in Taiwan (Cheng et al. 2016), Factors related to spiritual well-being in the last days of life in three East Asian countries: An international multicenter prospective cohort study, Palliative Medicine(Hiratsuka et.al,2021), A cross-cultural comparison of hospice development in Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan(Glass,et.al) etc to identify the development of the Buddhist Dharma among cancer patient and their family in Japan and Taiwan.This step is suitable for analyzing the similarities and possible gaps. The online field is conducted through taking field notes from the patients blog&mini log and their family members’ dairy blog in the online forum to help find the effective elements to the development of hospice palliative care involving Buddhist thoughts among cancer patient and their family in mainland China.As in this way can help to perceive more authentic emotion with the target group.Because this kind of resources are relatively limited,therefore,all the posts that can be found will be recorded. In terms of the data selection,some true factors that rightly exert the influence on the application to the Buddhism among cancer patient and their family in mainland China in hospice care are expected.They could be from every aspects of the society,namely patients and their family members,medical staff and hospital management including the Buddhist religion group.

Discussion/Conclusion

 Because of the shortage of the contemporary English academia resources among this topic in mainland China, the preliminary resources from Buddhist sutra and the secondary English resources tend to more precious,which brings the novelty into this research.Further more,what are the differences between the hospice care with and without Buddhism intervention while facing the death ? According to Harding,theological religiosity was the only one to have a significant effect on death acceptance and death anxiety (Harding,el.al,2005),it delivers the information that this research paper is on the right way that deserves to explore further.As the purpose and the value of this paper aims at attempting to integrate Buddhism teachings with medical hospice care among cancer patients and family members in China mainland, mastering interdisciplinary knowledge regarding many of the aspects become essentially important ,for instance,to disclose the historical evidence of Buddhism hospice care towards terminally ill patients and their families could give an enlightenment and a guidance to contemporary hospice care system in a more spiritual-care orientation,and to find the research answers by comparing the successful development cases in Japan and Taiwan in converse could affect the humanitarian progress in Chinese hospice care system.Though,the study has the limitation of taking face to face interview and getting more vivid reactions and attitudes from the target patients and their families,plus,during the covid time,it is uneasy to have access to go back to mainland China,the online field work makes sense as more exclusive expression of the authentic emotional thoughts which might not be displayed in front of the public from target patients can be collected.Most importantly,the study could in favor of diminishing people’s excruciation in dealing with facing death ,after all ,this is the destination which everyone will set foot on .
References :

Capitanio, J. (2013). Health, Illness, and the Body in Buddhist and Daoist Self-Cultivation. Brahman and Dao: Comparative Studies of Indian and Chinese Philosophy and Religion.

Concepts and definitions for “supportive care,” “best supportive care,” “palliative care,” and “hospice care” in the published literature, dictionaries, and textbooks. Supportive Care in Cancer, 21(3), 659–685. 

Salguero, C. P., & Macomber, A. (Eds.). (2020). Buddhist Healing in Medieval China and Japan. University of Hawai’i Press.
